greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Expansion of Sum_{p prime} x^p/(1 + x^p).
comment: a(n) is the number of prime divisors p|n such that n/p is odd, minus the number of prime divisors p|n such that n/p is even.
link: Robert Israel, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..10000
formula: If n is odd, a(n) = A001221(n).
L.g.f.: log(Product_{k>=1} (1 + x^prime(k))^(1/prime(k))) = Sum_{n>=1} a(n)*x^n/n. - _Ilya Gutkovskiy_, Jul 30 2018
example: The prime divisors of 12 are 2, 3. We see that 12/2 = 6, 12/3 = 4. None of those are odd, but both of them are even, so a(12) = -2.
The prime divisors of 30 are {2,3,5} with quotients {15,10,6}. One of these is odd and two are even, so a(30) = 1 - 2 = -1.
maple: if p > N then break fi;
results.author: _Gus Wiseman_, Jun 06 2018
